comments.commentBody: I'm wondering about this...the species couldn't have survived if the design was really that flawed, but maybe the problem is that babies have been growing at a rate that has outpaced women's abilities to adapt.  Vaginal delivery of a 6 pound baby sounds a lot more plausible than vaginal delivery of a 9 pounder--does that explain some of the increase in C-sections?

@ Rachel M.-

As far of the survival of the species goes, the only important thing is that the baby is born alive. Whether or not the mother survives after that doesn't matter as much, from an evolutionary perspective.

As I understand it, childbirth wasn't as difficult or dangerous before humans starting walking upright. (And as we started developing language and higher brain function, and therefore larger brains and head circumference). At that point, the shape of our pelvis changed, and childbirth became considerably more difficult.

Other primates who spend more time on all fours or in trees have a much easier time of it, due to the more accommodating shape of their pelvis and the smaller head size of infants.

I believe the rise in C-sections can be explained by several factors. For example, mothers are increasingly older (35+), have higher BMIs, and have a higher incidence of chronic conditions like diabetes and hypertension. Those are all risk factors.

the adjusted numbers reflect  the reality that used to kill women all over the world, for millenia, and still does anywhere women do not have access to health care.  childbirth is dangerous.  after my child was born i decided Nature had not provided us with a very good design here, regardless of current theories.

Yes, Mr. Gump there is skimming of wealth going on in this country, but your conclusion that the election doesn't matter I oppose.  In this election you can give over entirely to the wealth skimmers and and elect Mr. Romney and his masters into office, or you can work for change (and more change is needed) within the present administration.
But why is it that so many Americans believe liars?  That surely must be stupidity?

frankiethepunk -- That is a very good question. I have some experience with this, as a lawyer. Dealing with drug addicts, criminals, and witnesses with an agenda is excellent preparation for understanding Republican methods.

It is fatigue. A serial liar, known untrustworthy, lies to you and you catch them. They replace that with another lie and you catch that. Then again. They never tell the truth, just a new lie. Finally, you give up. You know they won't ever tell you the truth. But ultimately, many put down the last lie as "what they said."

The next time you question the same known serial liar, you don't even bother with that whole show. You just write down what they said, the first lie. You know it will not get any better, and you will just waste your time and energy, get upset.

The danger is that the first lie, when useful, will be used by the listener, who really does not believe it.

That is where we are now with Republicans.

There is a name for it in politics, the "Gish Gallop" method -- bury them in so many lies they can't even keep track. The basic lies get by, buried under the mountain of what does get caught enough to be distrusted. At bottom, it is the same fatigue.

The press bears serious responsibility for helping the liars, instead of doing its job.

Obama's plan did not work as well as he hoped. But: 1) he did not get the plan he wanted because the Republicans wouldn't do it; and 2) even what he did get did better than everyone else who tried what the Republicans wanted and still want.

Republicans are not stupid, just liars. They want tax cuts for themselves. They'll say it is austerity, or stimulus, or trickle down, or anything else. They just want the tax cuts. Any lie will do to get them.

It has nothing to do with what will work. It has nothing to do with anything they say at all. You have to get the basic principle: they're liars, and every single thing they say will be a lie. They just want the tax cuts.

The whistle blowing by Drake was under Bush, the case brought against him by the FBI was under Bush. The case was dismissed under Obama.
Seems the bad actors are the Cheney/Bush guys to me.
Yes, Din Tai Fung is the best. The Xiao Long Bao there is the most amazing thing. Although it is called Xiao Long Bao, it is very different from Xiao Long Bao in Mainland China.

I'm not against reinvention, but as someone who grew up eating traditional northern chinese dumplings it kind of pains me to see this (almost peasant) staple receiving that "it food" treatment and slowly becoming one more of those things that nobody sane could ever afford.
I have never seen anyone eat dumplings with their hands.  It's not meant to be a finger food.
Most of the small dumpling shops sell frozen bags to go for very cheap, like $8 for 50.
Do you mean Vegetarian Dim Sum House? On Pell? Yum.

This all makes me miss kreplach, which I used to make with my Grandma Fannie in Brighton Beach.  In retrospect, pretty plain, but I was never happier than those afternoons with her, and then serving them to our family in chicken soup.  We all have our dumplings, if we are lucky.

Pal, Copa America is the right title. America is the name of the continent from the Artic to the southern tip of Argentina & Chile.

I think is high time the US quit themselves called America and stop that stupidity of the Americas. You are the USA, plain and simple.
This is absolutely fantastic. I hope it becomes permanent. Also "Copa Americas" seems like the logical title.
cool
Then you might want to read the article, and listen to the NY interview and get a bit more background. In the context, it is inspiring.
You think its dumb because you dont understand the consequences that have cause Ai to be beaten and jailed. Look at one of the many documentaries doneon him.
The interview with the New Yorker makes me love him and his work even more. What an inspiring man!
Um, it's Korean, not Chinese.
They made Chinese lyrics for the song but not English ones?

Thank you Rima, for giving me new insight into what motivates the Republican Party.

Great perspective here:

"Paul Ryan may like to call himself a Catholic but his real religion is the GOP."

And here:

"The GOP has not only perfected the game of rigging politics, they've come up with their own religion".

It helps explain the rampant fanaticism and unrelenting acceptance of beliefs over facts that plague the new Republican Party.

I asked my doctor, who is very thorough and open-minded, about thermography. She said that there's a wide variance in the way these tests are conducted, and that the results are often inconclusive.

I have been searching for an alternative to mammography, too, and would like to know whether there's any hard statistical information about the efficacy of thermography.
My radiologist told me a diagnostic doesn't mean much more than extra pictures and I have implants so they would always do a digital with extra pics, and no it doesn't hurt at all.

I am 54, with no history of family breast cancer. I have had mammograms for many years; once I needed an ultrasound because there was something "suspicious" on my mammogram. The ultrasound--conducted by the radiologist, not a technician-- found nothing. The next year I had a "diagnostic mammogram"; I honestly don't know how that differed from a regular one.

Two thoughts: (1) the letter that the hospital sends me after each mammogram says quite starkly, "We are pleased to inform you that the results of your recent mammogram...did not show any sign of cancer." Although I'm obviously pleased by this, I always felt that perhaps the hospital should use softer language, such as "no abnormalities were detected", etc. (2) The letter has never said anything about the fact that I have dense tissue. I figured I didn't have dense tissue because my breasts are small and I am petite and relatively thin. However, this year, I looked at the results posted on my online medical account, and the letter sent to my doctor did contain a disclaimer that the negative results could not be definite because of my dense tissue. I assume the disclaimer is a standard one. My doctor never mentioned this at my routine exam last year.

I have just copied this article to bring to my gynecologist next week when I have my annual visit. I think I might go back to mammograms followed by ultrasounds, regardless of whether my insurance pays for it (I think it does).

Doubtful that the Jets would have won - or will win -the Super Bowl by being on the West Side.

They're playing in a brand new stadium and have nothing to show for it - simply a mediocre team (43 years and counting)

The Giants do, however, have nice new shiny Super Bowl rings and they play in the same stadium!

Andre- many outsiders have migratedto Brooklyn in recent years, and frankly, we natives don't have such a high opinion of you., no self respecting Brooklynite will ever set foot in that arena, if you want to patronize it with the rest of the sell-outs and phonies, we will not be surprised.
Jane, you know TYPEAB -- it refers to a blood bank, with blood type AB.

I can think of a whole lot of words for rear end that we haven't used, but they'd knock an emu on its bum.

I do have a cribbage game on my computer, sj, which I play from time to time. It's a pretty fair replication of the game, but it just shows your score and a not-very-good picture of the board and pegs. It's just not nearly as satisfying as counting and moving your peg around the little holes.

JaneDarlin, Actually, there's a rather huge Assortment of words to describe the human derriere, besides the two I've already touched on! Hehehehehe

"Hey! Fella, you got a problem with your hands?"

Howie

Another solveable creation, but words I didn't know, like TYPEAB and  ELO , but pleased to remember ENESCO and FIGARO and TRURO. Tho I've heard of TETRIS, I'm probably the only one who never played it. I tried to enter "bottom" instead of THE TOP -  that seemed more logical, and I thought it would go with TUSHIE. I think we've used up all the words for rear.

The Greeks made their contribution to western civilization over two-thousand years ago: arithmetic, geometry, trigonometry, architecture, and the geneses of philosophy, medicine, law, and pretty much anything that ends with the letters "logy." A good part of our western vocabularies comes from them, including most words that have double consonants and even simple words like "zoo." So let them work in their vineyards and drink their wine. (Which they perfected.)
Hopefully, our modern additions to their work will turn out as well.

I would hardly call a $800 Million stimulus package of which only half was actual stimulus massive. The rest was various tax cuts.

At the time your colleague Professor Krugman was calling for $2+ Trillion in actual stimulus dollars. That would have been massive and probably would have saved the world from a lot of our current economic problems. But that would have required Republican support and they aren't really interested in supporting government policies that actually solve problems.

Richard cherry picks his facts in order to erect his argument.  Unfortunately, his argument isn't very persuasive as a comment to this particular article.  I suggest he spend six months in Spain, the EU's model citizen in terms of fiscal discipline until the Mediterranean property bubble--largely driven by Brits and other non-Spaniards but financed by Spanish banks--burst.  The Spaniards then understandably tried to backstop their endangered banks.  Now they try to comply with the dictates of austerity.  They are enduring a downward economic spiral none of us can imagine.  Obama and Bernanke will eventually be recognized as the heroes of this era.

It makes sense if your goal is to destroy the Federal government and replace it with corporations.

That's essentially what "privatization" entails. We're seeing it in the prison system now. Essentially, the Right believes they can get even richer and more powerful if we have no government, except them of course, and we will have to pay them for the pleasure of being in jail.

As to how well this would work in practice, just check out our woeful health insurance industry.

It's terrible, we pay much more than other developed nations for health care and get worse results, and we're slaves to our health insurer, but, who cares? The rich are getting richer.

Not so hard really - austerity such as the Reagan/Volcker recessionary period keep a currency strong, reduce inflation, and protect creditors at the expense (bad pun) of borrowers.  The bailouts themselves rescued creditors, not the banks or borrowers.   Stimulus was the only real departure from that script...  There are choices, as Reagan proved on the backs of the unemployed, the idled manufacturing capacity, and the double-digit interest rates paid by borrowers at the time.  Did it feel better?  Not unless you were a loan shark....

It is difficult to understand why the European politicians implemented policies that defy logic, and in the end were counterproductive.

It is equally difficult to understand why the GOP is so determined to follow the same misguided policies.

It seems that in some economic schools the word "Keynesian" was evidently taught with disdain.

The GOP and the Europeans seem to think that by treating a starving patient by denying the patient food, that the patient will get better.

To put the matter in different terms, even a five year old would say, "no, don't starve the patient, but give it some food." But, these politicians can not see that.

These supposedly educated and intelligent leaders are unable to see the folly of their ways. Simply amazing, but yet, nothing that narrow minded politicians do should surprise us anymore.
